text: diet plays a big part in managing type 2
diabetes the key is to eat foods which
your body and the medication you take
can deal with
the following dietary methods can help
to reduce blood glucose levels
choosing foods which are absorbed more
slowly low gi foods
choosing foods with less carbohydrate
reducing your portion sizes
low gi foods
foods which take longer to be absorbed
into the bloodstream are said to have a
lower glycemic index
whole grain bread and basmati rice for
example are more slowly absorbed than
white bread and white rice
white versions of starchy carbohydrate
raises blood sugar very quickly whereas
whole grain foods with a lower gi raise
blood glucose levels more slowly giving
the body a better chance to deal with a
rise in blood sugar
choosing foods with less carbohydrate
if you choose foods with less
carbohydrate this can also help to
improve blood sugar levels
if you need to reduce your calorific
intake as well replacing starchy foods
such as potatoes with vegetables such as
cauliflower and broccoli is a good way
to help your blood sugar levels as well
as weight
reducing portion sizes
some of us may not be comfortable giving
up particular types of food
if this applies to you then another
option is to reduce portion sizes
reducing portion sizes of
carbohydrate-based foods will help to
improve blood sugar levels and decrease
your calorific intake
a good tip when reducing portion sizes
is to spend longer eating which will
help you to better enjoy the food and
also helps your body to register when
you are satisfied
